newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Di Pietro resigns as minister.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Di Pietro resigns as minister.

text.p: Antonio Di Pietro, a former magistrate who helped sink Italy's old governing class over corruption, resigned as public works minister on Thursday after coming under investigation himself, his spokesman said.
The spokesman said Di Pietro, named to Italy's centre-left government when it was formed in May, had sent his letter of resignation to Prime Minister Romano Prodi.

It was not immediately clear whether Di Pietro's resignation had been accepted. Prodi earlier on Thursday expressed support for his minister, who was a star of the Milan pool of "Clean Hands" anti-graft investigators until he quit in December 1994.
A non-political appointee to Prodi's cabinet, he was the first minister to resign. Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said he did not think his departure would threaten government stability.

Di Pietro's lawyer Massimo Dinoia earliler confirmed the former magistrate was the subject of a preliminary investigation. Newspapers said he was being probed over alleged irregularities in the way he conducted his inquiries.
"Enough is enough," D Pietro wrote in his letter of resignation, which said the decision was irreversible.
